#Text=Montreal/Plateau
#Text=The Plateau is a district in Montreal .
#Text=Get in
#Text=The Plateau is adjacent to the downtown core , so there are many ways to access it .
#Text=Avenue du Parc , boulevard Saint-Laurent , rue Saint-Denis , and rue Papineau run north/south through the Plateau and are paralleled by dozens of side streets in between .

#Text=East/west , rue Sherbrooke , avenue des Pins , avenue Rachel , avenue du Mont-Royal , and boulevard Saint-Joseph bisect the Plateau , with Mont-Royal carrying a lot of shops , bars , and restaurants .
#Text=All of these streets are accessible by car ( though Staint-Laurent is one way , going north ) and served by many taxi companies .
#Text=Each of these streets and a few others are served by bus routes run by the STM .
#Text=In addition , the Orange line of the Montreal Metro runs underneath rue Berri , adjacent to rue Saint-Denis .
#Text=Sherbrooke , Mont-Royal , and Laurier Metro stations are also on the Plateau .
#Text=Bike routes are few but still useful .

#Text=There are separated bike lanes on avenue Rachel from Parc Mont-Royal to boulevard Lafontaine and rue Brébeuf from parc Lafontaine to parc Laurier , and there are painted bike lanes along rue Saint-Urbain , rue Milton , rue Prince-Arthur , and rue Saint-Joseph .
#Text=These lanes are generally not respected by Montreal drivers , so watch out .
#Text=In addition , several of these lanes are not plowed during the winter , making them all but impassible following heavy snow .
#Text=Buildings
#Text=The most dominant architectural feature of the Plateau is the endless rows of Montreal duplexes and triplexes that house the majority of the Plateau 's population .
#Text=These buildings date from the early 20th century and , with their distinctive exterior staircases and wrought-iron ornamentation , have come to define the visual landscape of the Plateau .
#Text=In addition , there are a few buildings of note scattered around the Plateau .
#Text=The Warshaw building ( boulevard Saint-Laurent and rue Bagg ) dates from the 1920s and was the Plateau 's first skyscraper .
#Text=Though it has only seven floors , it is a distinctive feature of the neighbourhood .
#Text=Farther north , 4020 boulevard Saint-Laurent is recognisable by its impressive refinished neo-Art Deco exterior .
#Text=Also , there are many large churches from the 19th century and the early 20th century .
#Text=Most notable of these would be the oriental looking St. Michael the Archangel , located at 5590 rue Saint-Urbain at rue Saint-Vincent ouest .
#Text=On the southern end of the Plateau , on the edge of the McGill University ghetto , is the Galleries du Parc , a large 1960s-era urban redevelopment project .
#Text=The Galleries are comprised of four large buildings , three of them devoted to apartments and the fourth devoted to office space .
#Text=In addition , a former hotel , now a residence of McGill University , and an underground shopping complex are part of the Galleries project .
#Text=The underground mall , though small , contains a variety of shops and services including the Parc Cinema , showing art-house and second-run films .
#Text=Parks
#Text=The Plateau is bordered on two sides by large parks .
#Text=To the west is Parc du Mont-Royal , designed by Frederic Law Olmstead in the 1880s , and a dominant feature of the Montreal landscape .
#Text=The park is well used for recreation , biking , hiking , cross-country skiing in the winter , as well as the weekly Tam Tams celebration during the summer months .
#Text=Parc du Mont-Royal is safe and accessible by the adjacent Parc Jeanne-Mance , listed below , and by Ave du Parc .
#Text=To the east is Parc Lafontaine , also listed below .
#Text=Parc Jeanne-Mance , between ave du Parc , ave du Mont-Royal , ave de l'Esplanade , and ave des Pins ( bus 11 , 29 , 55 , 80 , 97 , 129 , or 144 ) .
#Text=Located in the western part of the Plateau , adjacent to Parc du Mont-Royal .
#Text=At the corner of Mont-Royal and Parc is an art deco fountain dedicated in honour of Louis Rubenstein , the father of Canadian figure skating .
#Text=Parc Lafontaine , between ave du Parc Lafontaine , rue Rachel , ave Papineau , and rue Sherbrooke ( metro Sherbrooke or Mont-Royal , bus 11 , 14 , 24 , 29 , or 45 ) .
#Text=Located in the eastern part of the Plateau , the park is well-manicured and includes an artificial lake , bike paths , sporting facilities , and an outdoor amphitheater .
#Text=Very popular during summer .
#Text=Carré Saint-Louis ( Square Saint-Louis ) , between ave Laval , rue Saint-Denis , and the two sides of rue du Square Saint-Louis ( metro Sherbrooke , bus 24 , 20 , or 144 ) .
#Text=A smaller park , Carré Saint-Louis is at the east end of the Prince Arthur pedestrian mall , next to rue Saint-Denis .
#Text=Though a fraction of the size of either Parc LaFontaine or Parc du Mont-Royal , it is a popular and scenic local destination .
#Text=Two fountains , bike paths , and easy access to a number of restaurants and shops provide a comforting background and a relaxing setting .
#Text=On a side note , many of the gags on the television show Just For Laughs are performed in this park .
#Text=The park is also notable for the colourful Victorian rowhouses that surround it .
#Text=Mount Royal Park , 1260 Chemin Remembrance , ☏ +1 514-843-8240 , ✉ info@lemontroyal.qc.ca .
#Text=Has an artificial lake , many paths through the wood , and the best view on the city of Montreal .
#Text=Art
#Text=There are also examples of impressive urban tableaux and graffiti art found throughout the Plateau .
#Text=The side streets to the east of boulevard Saint-Laurent are well known for this , particularly avenue Duluth .
#Text=Place Roy , rue Roy est and rue Saint-André ( metro Sherbrooke , bus 14 , 24 , 30 , or 144 ) .
#Text=Public art piece in a small square featuring a stone map of the world and several scattered bronze chairs .
#Text=Do
#Text=The Plateau area is a great place to walk around , shop , go to restos and clubs , or just hang out .
#Text=There is always something interesting happening here , a very cool ambiance .
#Text=It borders Mile End and Latin Quarter , both very cool areas themselves .
#Text=Just get off the orange line at Mont-Royal or Sherbrooke and start walking up St. Denis or St. Laurent .
#Text=Maison de la culture du Plateau-Mont-Royal , 465 ave du Mont-Royal est ( between rue Rivard and rue Berri ; metro Mont-Royal , bus 11 , 30 , or 97 ) , ☏ +1 514-872-2266 .
#Text=Tu - Th 1PM-7PM , F - Su 1PM-5PM .
#Text=Exhibits local artists .
#Text=Free .

#Text=Théâtre de Verdure , in Parc Lafontaine near rue Duluth and ave du Parc-Lafontaine ( metro Mont-Royal or Sherbrooke , bus 11 , 14 , or 29 ) , ☏ +1 514-872-4041 , ✉ acces_culture@ville.montreal.qc.ca .
#Text=30 Jun-17 Aug , W - Su 7:30PM .
#Text=3000-seat outdoor theater open for a summer program of dance , music , movies , and theater .
#Text=Plan to line up early for the popular symphonies in the park series or just join the crowd of picnickers on the grass around the lake .
#Text=Free-$ 30 depending on the show .
